prompt: Write a poem about name badge in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nimblebadge

'Twas clippy, and the stickered plate
Did glint and glimmer on the breast;
All plasticky was its estate,
With letters boldly pressed.

"Beware the Nimblebadge, my friend!
The pins that catch, the clasp that bites!
Beware the coffee-stain, and shun
The frumptious meeting-sites!"

He took his Sharpie pen in hand:
Long time his proper name he sought—
Then rested by the office stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in lanyard-thought he stood,
The Nimblebadge, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the meeting-wood,
And scribbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The trusty marker wrote it plain!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went displaying back again.

"And hast thou slain the Nimblebadge?
Come to my desk, my beamish boy!
Oh, frabjous day! Display away!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas clippy, and the stickered plate
Did glint and glimmer on the breast;
All plasticky was its estate,
With letters boldly pressed.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on bittersweet victory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pyrrhic Jabber

'Twas brillig when the victor's cry
Did swirl and shimmer 'cross the vale;
The blood-soaked banners waving high,
While triumph's price turned warriors pale.

"Beware the cost of glory's might!
The claws that catch, the teeth that bite!"
Yet forth they charged with blazing eyes,
Till foes lay scattered 'neath grey skies.

And as the vorpal blade went snick!
The victory they sought was won;
But empty thrones and hearts too quick
Showed winning left them all undone.

Now galumphing through hollow halls,
The heroes weep behind their walls;
Their frabjous day has come and passed—
A conquest far too sweet to last.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about a promise kept in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Vowerment

'Twas brillig when the solemn vow
Did swish and shimmer in the glow,
All binding were the words somehow,
That whispered soft and low.

"Beware the broken promise-beast!
The jaws that break, the tongue that lies!
Keep faith until the very least
Of pledges truly flies!"

With honor-sword in hand they stood,
Time whiffled through the tulgey year,
Through storm and shine and bad and good,
The promise crystal clear.

And as in steadfast thought they stayed,
The vow-light burned with faithful flame,
Through every choice that had been made,
Till triumph-time it came!

'Twas brillig when the promise true
Did shine accomplished in the light,
All faithful words, both old and new,
Had conquered promise-night!
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about paperclip chain in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Clipperchain

'Twas linky, and the slidey clips
Did wind and wimble on the desk;
All bendy were the metalships,
And the long chain arabesqued.

"Beware the Clipperchain, my friend!
The links that snap, the points that catch!
Beware the breaking bend, and shun
The frumious papersnatch!"

He took his trusty clips in hand:
Long time the silver join he sought—
Then rested he by the paper tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in ofish thought he stood,
The Clipperchain, with chains of steel,
Came winding through the stationary wood,
And rattled as it wheeled!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The metal links went snicker-snack!
He linked them all, and with their fall
He made his chain click-clack.

"And hast thou chained the Clipperchain?
Come link with me, my beamish boy!
O frabjous chain!" He chortled plain,
And twisted in his joy.

'Twas linky, and the slidey clips
Did wind and wimble on the desk;
All bendy were the metalships,
And the long chain arabesqued.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on control theory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Feedback Loop

'Twas control-time, and the PID
Did track and settle in its space:
All stable were the poles agreed,
And errors did erase.

"Beware the Unstable State, my friend!
The gains that spike, the phase that lags!
Beware the Bode plot, and attend
The Nyquist's zigzag flags!"

He took his sturdy transfer blade:
Long time the feedback foe he sought—
So rested he by the time-domain,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in closed-loop thought he stood,
The Unstable State, with margins high,
Came oscillating through the wood,
And resonated nigh!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The transfer blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went compensating back.

"And hast thou slain the Unstable State?
Come to my arms, my servo boy!
O feedback day! Response, hurray!"
He dampened in his joy.

'Twas control-time, and the PID
Did track and settle in its space:
All stable were the poles agreed,
And errors did erase.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about error correction in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Checksumwock

'Twas bitwise, and the parity checks
Did parse and parcel through the frames;
All hamming were the error specs,
And the hash codes came.

"Beware the Checksumwock, my son!
The bits that flip, the bytes that fail!
Beware the CRC-sum, and shun
The frumious data trail!"

He took his error sword in hand;
Long time the hex code foe he sought—
So rested he by the buffer tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in buffer rage he stood,
The Checksumwock, with eyes of flame,
Came corrupting through the protocol wood,
And garbled as it came!

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The binary blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He fixed the packets back.

"And hast thou slain the Checksumwock?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O redundant day! FEC! FRA!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas bitwise, and the parity checks
Did parse and parcel through the frames;
All hamming were the error specs,
And the hash codes came.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about evening breeze in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Whisperlisk at Dusk

'Twas slifting, and the windywakes
Did swish and sustle through the trees;
All whimsome were the nightingshakes,
And moonmist made its pleas.

"Beware the Whisperlisk, my friend!
The voice that sings, the breath that sighs!
Beware the Murmurwend, and shun
The fumbling flutterskies!"

He took his whisperword in hand,
Long time the breezesome foe he sought—
Then rested he 'neath swayling bough,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in airish thought he stood,
The Whisperlisk, with gentle grace,
Came drifting through the tulgey wood,
And swooshed about his face!

One, two! One, two! The evening air
Went twirling, spinning all around!
He caught the breeze, and with a care,
It danced without a sound.

"And hast thou caught the Whisperlisk?
Come dance with me, my swirling boy!
O frabjous night! What gentle risk!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas slifting, and the windywakes
Did swish and sustle through the trees;
All whimsome were the nightingshakes,
And moonmist made its pleas.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on zebra crossing in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Zebberous Road

'Twas stripling white on tarmac black,
The pedestrians did pause and wait,
All nervous were the motormack,
As crossers congregate.

"Beware the zebberous stripes, my son!
The laws that bind, the lines that show!
Beware the speeding cars that run,
And mind which way you go!"

They took their cautious steps with care,
Long time the painted path they sought—
Then rested by the curbing there,
In crosswise thought.

And as in safety stance they stood,
The zebberous path, with rules so true,
Came guiding through the neighborhood,
Safe passage through and through!

"And hast thou crossed the zebberous way?
Come tell me now, oh fearless child!"
"Oh frabjous day! Safe path! Hooray!"
They chortled in their smile.

'Twas stripling white on tarmac black,
The pedestrians did cross with grace,
All peaceful now the motormack,
In ordered time and space.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about moving day in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Packerwack

'Twas moving day, and all around
The cardboard boxes strewed the ground
The bubble wrap went snip and pop
While dust buns danced atop

"Beware the Packerwack, my friend!
The tape that binds, the backs that bend!
Beware the Staircase-beast, and shun
The dreaded Moving Van!"

He took his dolly cart in hand,
Long time the heavy couch he planned—
Then rested by the doorway there,
And wiped his brow with care

And as in stressful thought he stood,
The Packerwack, with boxes good,
Came thumping down the hallway fair,
And tumbled down the stair!

One, two! One, two! The contents flew!
The socks and books fell through and through
He gathered all, packed neat and tight,
And trudged into the night

"And hast thou moved thy dwelling place?
Come rest thee here, show thy face!"
"Oh, frabjous day! The deed is done!"
He sighed, at setting sun.

'Twas moving day, and all around
New rooms with treasures could be found
The boxes empty, home at last,
The Packerwack had passed.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about burnt toast in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crumblewock

'Twas toasting, and the crispybread
Did brown and sizzle on the grate:
All darker were the crusts that spread,
While timer dial was too late.

"Beware the Crumblewock, my son!
The smoke that rises, scents that bite!
Beware the scraper-tool, and shun
The blackened bits that might!"

He took his butter knife in hand:
Long time the charred remains he scraped—
Then rested he by garbage can,
And stood awhile and gaped.

And, as in smoky thought he stood,
The Crumblewock, with flames of black,
Came wafting through the neighborhood,
Setting alarms to crack!

One, two! One, two! The butter flew!
The knife went snicker-snack!
He scraped it clean, and with its sheen
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Crumblewock?
Come to my arms, my breadish boy!
O frabjous day! What luck! What luck!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas toasting, and the crispybread
Did brown and sizzle on the grate:
All darker were the crusts that spread,
While timer dial was too late.
label: high
